issues.title: Discuss RSA_F4 vs RSA_3
issues.author: kwlyeo
issues.body: Section 4.3: Discuss reasoning for choosing e = RSA_3 as opposed to e = RSA_F4 (0x10001)?

issues.title: Add RSAPBSSA Variants (Section 6)
issues.author: kwlyeo
issues.body:
One variant is where we consider a slightly different public key augmentation. The current algorithm guarantees that chosen new e is coprime to \phi(N) by restricting the length. In general, we could have a variant where we do not restrict the length. This would have the side-effect that the resulting e is not coprime to \phi(N). However, this is unlikely since as long as e is odd, then you would have found a prime factor of N and be able to break the RSA assumption.

Discuss and potentially add this into Section 6 of variants.

issues.title: Nitpicks in Section 4.5-4.6
issues.author: kwlyeo
issues.body:
Section 4.5 uses different format than other sections.

Section 4.6: Would it be clearer to set lambda_len = (kLen / 2) - 2? It is functionally the same, but maybe makes it clear that it has to be smaller than kLen.

Both above are nitpicks and optional to fix. I can take a crack if you agree on the changes.

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body: I definitely agree with the proposed changed to lambda_len. Maybe we can simply do lambda_len - 2 in step 8?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: What is the reason to choose lambda_len - 2?

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body: Like Kevin said, it will make it clear to the reader that the outputted e' is always <= lambda_len -2 (as we clear the top two bits)? But we can defer to your best judgement on this.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: It just seems sort of more complicated 🤷 Is there a technical reason to not just use lambda_len and then clamp the necessary number of bits?

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body: I really don't have a strong preference either way. :)

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: OK, let's close this then and revisit later if needed!

issues.title: Forgetting to multiply by e?
issues.author: kwlyeo
issues.body:
In Section 4.6, I think we need to multiply the augmentation by the original e.

Step 8 should become "output pkM = (n, e * e')"

issues.title: Losing a bit in AugmentPublicKey
issues.author: kwlyeo
issues.body:
Right now, the augmentation, e', is chosen to be length kLen / 2 - 2 where kLen is the length of the RSA modulus. We do this by choosing a random string of bit length kLen / 2, then clear the two-most top bits and change the last bit to 1.

I think we could get away with kLen / 2 - 1. As the prime factors of the RSA modulus are length kLen / 2, we can pick any odd number with length at most kLen / 2 - 1.

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body:
So I think we cannot do that. Here is why:
1) e' needs to be co-prime to phi(N) = 4p'q'. 
2) p' and q' are of lengths kLen / 2 - 1 (where p and q are of lengths  kLen / 2).
3) Hence we compute an e' of length kLen / 2 - 2.

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body: Note that p = 2p' + 1 and q = 2q' +1 where p, q, p' , q' are all primes.

comments.author: kwlyeo
comments.body: Ah, off-by-one error. Makes sense. Resolving this issue.

issues.title: Section 4.1: SafePrime(bits)
issues.author: Guss123
issues.body: The outputted safe prime is of length at least bits + 1, instead of bits.

issues.title: Section 4.2: Encoding of the msg and metadata pair (concat(msg, metadata))
issues.author: Guss123
issues.body: We need to come up with a unique encoding. One suggestion is using using 32 bits / INT for the length of metadata, then put the message and then put the metadata; So concat(|metadata|,msg, metadata). Assuming msg is of length x bytes and metadata is of length y bytes, then the encoding will be of x+y+4 bytes. WDYT?

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body: The same encoding will also be used in Section 4.4 (Finalize Protocol) and Section 4.5 ( Verification).

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I think it's best if the message is not limited by input length restrictions, so bounding the metadata seems fine. I think length-prefixing the metadata is a reasonable way to deal with this. I would suggest: `|metadata| || metadata || msg`

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body: I approve |metadata| || metadata || msg where |metadata| can fit in 4Bytes (Int).

issues.title: HKDF params
issues.author: Guss123
issues.body:
1) Do we need to mention the hash function used (i.e. SHA384)?
2) hkdf_salt = concat(info, 0x00) but then hkdf_salt is passed to HKDF as IKM. We should update the variable name to avoid confusion. 
3) hkdf_info = int_to_bytes(n, kLen) and then it is passed as INFO to HKDF. In our implementations though, this is passed as salt to HKDF. We should correct that in the draft, as the info param we have been passing to HKDF is simply []byte("PBRSA") (which also should be added).

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
1. Yeah, we should mention that!
2. Yeah, I don't love it, but I went with `hkdf_salt` as the variable name to hopefully avoid confusion. I'm open to alternatives.
3. Right, yes, thanks. I'll correct this in the pseudocode.

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body:
For 2. maybe the variable name could be hkdf_input? But I get your hesitation for calling it keying material.

Thanks!

issues.title: Thoughts on input_msg = Prepare(msg)
issues.author: Guss123
issues.body: We need to add a section on Prepare protocol. Moreover, in section 4 instead of input_msg as input to Blind and Finalize, we write msg. This can be confusing so it should be updated to input_msg OR we should flip "input_msg = Prepare(msg)" to "msg = Prepare(input_msg)"

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
We already have text that covers this:

```
The Prepare function is as specified in {{Section 4.1 of RSABSSA}}.
```

I don't think we need to repeat that section inline here. Would you agree?

issues.title: Mind your ps and qs
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
> a key pair MUST be the product of two safe primes p and q. A safe prime p is a prime number such that p = 2q + 1, where q is also a prime number

A lazy reader might infer that the values in the key pair have the relationship p=2q+1.  Consider using different labels for the definitional part to avoid this confusion.

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body: Oops did not get this reviewed by mistake but fixed the issue. Closing it now. Please re-open if needed.

issues.title: Algorithms scroll horizontally
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
...or overflow the page.  See https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-amjad-cfrg-partially-blind-rsa-00#section-4.2-4

Consider avoiding the use of `<artwork>` and instead use lists so that the styling can be taken care of for you.

issues.title: Should Finalize output msg_prime?
issues.author: smhendrickson
issues.body:
When writing a Token Verification procedure Ghous and I noted that an implementer must create the authenticator input exactly as described by the `msg_prime` creation:

```
1. msg_prime = concat("msg", int_to_bytes(len(metadata), 4), metadata, msg)
``` 

For example, this is an excerpt from [public metadata issuance](https://smhendrickson.github.io/draft-hendrickson-privacypass-public-metadata-issuance/draft-hendrickson-privacypass-public-metadata.html#name-token-verification):

```
token_authenticator_input =  concat("msg",
    int_to_bytes(len(Token.metadata), 4),
    Token.metadata,
    token_input)
valid = RSASSA-PSS-VERIFY(pkM,
                          token_authenticator_input,
                          Token.authenticator)
```

Should we instead have the Finalize method output `msg_prime` so it can be forwarded directly to the Verifier without reconstruction?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: This is a good idea. In the RSABSSA spec, the protocol outputs the "prepared message" (the thing signed) as well as the signature. We should do the same thing here. I don't think it needs to be an explicit output of `Finalize`, but rather something that client implementations can choose to provide to callers as needed.

issues.title: Use `info` instead of `metadata`
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: The [POPRF spec](https://cfrg.github.io/draft-irtf-cfrg-voprf/draft-irtf-cfrg-voprf.html) uses the term `info` as the public value for the POPRF. I suggest we reuse `info` here for consistency.

Thanks for these changes. Lets just say `hkdf_salt = int_to_bytes(n, kLen)` instead of calling it `hkdf_info`.

`expanded_bytes = HKDF(IKM=hkdf_input, salt=hkdf_salt, info="PBRSA", L=hkdf_len)`

pulls.title: Augment to Derive, dropping exponentiation
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body: Also, use "info" consistently as the public metadata parameter name to align the POPRF terminology from draft-irtf-cfrg-voprf.

comments.body: I think we can drop e and d from here.

Can remove e and d as follows:

sk = (p, q, phi)
pk = n
Why would we remove `e` and `d`?
This will take n aka modulus as input. Some calls are passing pk to it and some aren't. All calls need to be corrected to pass modulus to DerivePublicKey.

Because e & d are not used anywhere anymore. Before we would use e & d in the augment functions. However, in the new Derive* functions, they are not needed. The public key one would only need modulus n whereas the secret key one would need p, q, phi.
Ah, yes, good catch! I'll add `pk` back to the list of parameters, since that's what has `n`.
Let's address this in a separate change.

pulls.title: EMSA-PSS-ENCODE using bit_len(n) - 1
pulls.author: smhendrickson
pulls.body:
EMSA-PSS-ENCODE using bit_len(n) - 1

This ensures that the verification as defined in https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8017#section-8.1.2 matches, in case a verifier is using a standard   RSASSA-PSS-VERIFY implementation.

pulls.title: modulus_len must be a power of 2
pulls.author: smhendrickson
pulls.body: To better align with the paper and implementation.

comments.body:
```suggestion
- modulus_len, the length in bytes of the RSA modulus n. This MUST be a power of 2.
```

pulls.title: Update to FIPS 186-5
pulls.author: smhendrickson
pulls.body:
FIPS 186-4 will soon be withdrawn, so we should refer to 186-5.

Additionally, we should be more precise with our reference to 'standard' RSA-PSS libraries, as SYMCRYPT doesn't support exponents larger than 64 bits:
https://github.com/microsoft/SymCrypt/blob/b4f07a34bdb970e8690dc13a98fb9fb77edc0f50/inc/symcrypt.h#L6705

pulls.title: Take mod n of z during computation
pulls.author: smhendrickson
pulls.body: This may make the implementation of `z * inv mod n` on the next line less error prone.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I'm not really sure I understand this change. In what way is the following line (`z * inv`) error prone?

comments.author: smhendrickson
comments.body: The added implementation complexities aren't entirely clear here, so we will drop this PR

pulls.title: Adding more information regarding is_prime and random_prime.
pulls.author: Guss123

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Why is this change needed?

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body: Latest FIPS specification makes a distinction between provable and probable primes. This change reinforces that we are fine with probable primes. No strong opinion from my end. We can close with comment if you think it is not needed in the context of this draft.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> Latest FIPS specification makes a distinction between provable and probable primes. This change reinforces that we are fine with probable primes. No strong opinion from my end. We can close with comment if you think it is not needed in the context of this draft.

I would prefer a slightly different approach. Namely, I would add some more context about what happens if these functions fail (return composite instead of prime numbers, for example). We can then point to that context when needed, e.g.:

```
- random_prime(b): Return a random prime number of length b bits. See {{prime-context}} for more information about this function.

<snip>
<appendix>

# Primes and Primality Tests {#prime-context}

The functions random_prime and is_prime likely use probabilistic primality tests internally. As a result, it is possible for these functions to return incorrect values. The consequence of an incorrect value is TODO.
```

pulls.title: DOS Attacks as explained currently, are not possible for RSAPBSSA
pulls.author: Guss123
pulls.body: Making the section on DOS attacks more accurate and nuanced.

comments.author: Guss123
comments.body:
"as previously stated, the attacker can choose the metadata and therefore choose the length of the public exponent" 

I dont see that in this section. IF the attacker is able to choose the length of the public exponent only then it can launch DOS attack with bigger and bigger public exponents. However in our protocol, the we fix public exponent length (as we fix the HKDF output length) so whatever public metadata the attacker picks, the output size of public exponent is alway the same.

reviews.author: chris-wood
reviews.body: The existing text seems correct and is more concise. The new text is longer and seems incorrect. In particular, "Fortunately, RSAPBSSA does not provide the flexibility of picking the length of the derived public exponent and thus we avoid this situation" is wrong since, as previously stated, the attacker can choose the metadata and therefore choose the length of the public exponent.

pulls.title: Note on side channel attacks
pulls.author: Guss123
pulls.body: Adding explicit reference to side channel section of the original RSABSSA document and commenting on the fact the the public exponent inversion modulo private key material has a potential for side channel attack. Adding a potential defense as well in the form of a constant time GCD algorithm.

pulls.title: Fix DerivePublicKey definition, and improve test vector consistency
pulls.author: thibmeu
pulls.body:
Mostly minor tweaks:
* slice in DerivePublicKey did not match it's definition. This change adds a start
* DerievePublicKey only needs n, remove e, which is not passed to DeriveKeyPair for instance
* update test vector to match the name they present in the draft
* add a definition for string when used as byte string. Otherwise concat is hard to read
